Most investors understand there's no actual mathematical benefit to a stock split . Double the number of a company's outstanding shares simply cuts the value of those shares in half . No net value is created in the process, no matter how many new shares are issued .  Streaming giant Netflix hasn't made any official indication that a stock split is in the works, for the record . There are a couple of good reasons to expect one soon . One company's stock is worth buying, while the other one is arguably best left avoided .  Netflix stock could be in the works for a possible 7-for-1 split . The stock's already-frothy price point makes it unapproachable for individual investors . CEO Reed Hastings recently suggested he's aiming for atrillion-dollar market capas soon as 2030 . That would mean a doubling of the company's current market value .  The streaming industry is at a turning point, and Netflix is coming out of this turn as a clear leader . Most U.S. households (which is the industry's most important market) are tightening up their streaming budgets .  Netflix has become such a dominant name within the premium video-on-demand business that it's almost synonymous with it . It may well reach that trillion-dollar market cap mark within the next five years . It's also the one service they're least likely to cancel, with its consistent industry-low churn rate of less than 2% .
